user.biography: News and analysis with a global perspective. We’re here to help you understand the world around you. Click to learn more about any post 👇

node.text:
The pandemic not only disrupted education—it also thrust technology onto a sector which historically has been slow to adopt it. Will classrooms ever be the same again?

Cover image credit: Ben Hasty/MediaNews Group/Reading Eagle via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: how tech will transform your kids’ education

node.text: The race between covid-19 vaccines and variants is on. Alok Jha, The Economist’s science correspondent, and Natasha Loder, our health policy editor, discuss what this means for the future. Cover image credit: Alamy

node.title: Covid-19: can vaccines keep up with variants?

node.text: The Taliban’s swift return to power in Afghanistan has shocked the world and humiliated America. What effect will this have on the international standing of the US and on global security? Our experts answer your questions. Cover credit: AP

node.title: Afghanistan: how the Taliban weakened America

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.text:
Most governments recognise that vaccination is the fastest way out of the pandemic, but in many places hesitancy is hindering the roll-out. Should employers—or even governments—force people to have the vaccine? We answer your questions.

Cover image credit:

node.text:
The covid-19 pandemic has reinforced humanity’s dependence on modern tech, but the same tools that enable remote working are also being used to spread disinformation and perpetuate cybercrime. Ambivalence towards technology is nothing new.

Cover image credit: Scott Strazzante/The San Francisco Chronicle via Getty Images

node.text:
More than 50 countries around the world have pledged to become net zero. But what does net zero actually mean—and is it achievable?

Cover image credit: Brandon Thibodeaux/ The New York Times / Redux / eyevine

node.text:
In the past couple of weeks South Africa has witnessed the worst violence since the end of apartheid in 1994. Our correspondent in Johannesburg explains what he has seen on the streets and why the country is in crisis. 

Cover credit: Getty Images

node.title: South Africa: what's behind the riots?

node.text:
In America, the intelligence services deem far-right extremism a greater domestic threat than Islamist terrorism. The pandemic has exacerbated the spread of white supremacism and neo-Nazism.

Cover image credit: Michael Nigro/Pacific Press/LightRocket via Getty Images

node.title: Fortnite to far right: the rise of digital extremism

node.text:
Across much of the world, covid-19 restrictions are starting to ease. The Economist has crunched the data to calculate how close countries are to pre-pandemic levels of normality—but will life ever be the same again? 

Click on the link in our bio to visit our website and explore our interactive normalcy tracker. It covers 50 countries which account for 76% of the world’s population and 90% of its GDP.

Cover image credit: Lluis Gene/AFP via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: why your life will never be the same again

node.text:

node.text: For most of 2020 the theory that covid-19 leaked from a Chinese lab was dismissed as unlikely. In the past few months it has gained currency. Our experts explain why. Cover credit: Getty Images

node.title: Did covid-19 leak from a Chinese lab?

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 09, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Leaders Boris Johnson deserves credit for reforming Britain's social care'.

node.text:
Boris Johnson unveiled a plan to break an election promise and raise taxes by 0.5% of GDP. The money will go to Britain’s National Health Service and social care, including residential care for the elderly. ⁠
⁠
The reform was necessary, but the way it is being paid for is far from ideal.⁠
⁠
Outrageously, income from pensions and property will escape higher levies, meaning many well-off elderly voters will be spared from paying anything for a reform that largely benefits them. ⁠
⁠
Had the government raised income tax instead, every generation would have contributed.⁠
⁠
Mr Johnson’s self-reinvention as a politician willing to take an unpopular but necessary decision is welcome. ⁠
⁠
Many more such decisions will be needed, preferably with better funding mechanisms. Tap on the link in our bio to read more.⁠
⁠
Credit: Glyn Kirk/Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in London, United Kingdom. May be an image of text that says 'Finance & economics Could climate change trigger a financial crisis? A lot hangs on governments'.

node.text:
Just how financially damaging does climate risk stand to be?⁠
⁠
Early stress tests by central banks and disclosures of companies are starting to shed light on the question, and suggest that the impact on large banks and insurers may be manageable. ⁠
⁠
But a lot hangs on whether governments set out a clear path for reducing emissions, such as through carbon taxes and energy-efficiency standards, giving banks enough time to prepare. ⁠
⁠
To read how climate change can affect the financial system, click on the link in our bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 08, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Asia The Delta variant has brought devastation to South-East Asia'.

node.text:
All through 2020 and the early part of this year, it looked like South-East Asia had escaped the worst of the pandemic. ⁠
⁠
But no longer. By the end of August, South-East Asia had recorded some 217,000 deaths from covid, about 2.6 times its total just three months earlier. ⁠
⁠
When the highly infectious Delta variant arrived in the region this year, it encountered a population that lacked any immunity, was complacent after a covid-free year and was defended by public-health measures designed for the milder, original form of the virus. ⁠
⁠
The worst may be over for South-East Asia, at least for now. New infections are declining sharply in Malaysia, Thailand and Indonesia.⁠
⁠
Click on the link in our bio to read why the disease's effects will long be felt in hunger, unemployment and lost opportunities in the region. ⁠
⁠
Credit: Aditya Aji/ Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in New York, New York. May be an image of skyscraper.

node.text:
In some ways America is worse off now than it was on September 10th 2001: more anxious, more polarised, less trusting. New York City, though, is better.⁠
⁠
For New Yorkers staggered by the shock of 9/11, rebuilding became a rallying cause, a way of not letting the terrorists win.⁠
⁠
The residential population of Lower Manhattan more than doubled between 2001 and 2020, as did the number of residential units. New York’s population, infrastructure, and business boomed in their post-tragedy revival. ⁠
⁠
Tap on the link in our bio to read more about how New York built back better after the worst day in the city’s history.⁠
⁠
Credit: Ashley Gilbertson/New York Times/Redux/eyevine

node.text:
“To have social condemnation with no route to social forgiveness really doesn't work.” Jon Fasman, our US digital editor, and John Prideaux, our US editor, join “Checks and Balance” to examine the threat from the illiberal left.⁠
⁠
Also on the podcast: a loose set of once-radical ideas about identity, social justice and self-expression has leapt from university campuses to permeate politics and the press, spilling onto the streets and beginning to spread into schools. We investigate how this progressive revolution is changing America. Are business leaders using wokeness for profit? And how should liberals respond to the threat from the illiberal left?⁠
⁠
We hear from Robin DiAngelo, best-selling author of “Nice Racism”, learn from the panic over political correctness three decades ago and speak to entrepreneur Vivek Ramaswamy, author of “Woke, Inc”.⁠
⁠
To learn more about politics in America, click the link in our bio to listen to “Checks and Balance”

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 08, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'HARD ACTS TO FOLLOW FROM ANGELA MERKEL TO THE QUEEN'.

node.text:
What do Angela Merkel, Steve Jobs and Nelson Mandela have in common? They’re all tough acts to follow. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
It takes a certain kind of bravery to risk being the whimper that follows someone else’s bang. After the star, the understudy. Beyond the mountain, the foothill. The show must go on.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
When Mrs Merkel steps down some time after this month’s election, anyone navigating Germany’s political topography is going to need a new map.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Every new Apple executive recruit undergoes a training programme designed to make you think like Mr Jobs. Faintly culty, but it seems to work: the company is now worth over $1trn. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
From the Queen to Tony Blair and Diana Rigg, click the link in bio to read some more of history's hardest acts to follow.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Illustrations: Jake Read ⁠⁠
Additional images: Getty, Shutterstock

Photo by The Economist on September 08, 2021. May be an image of 1 person.
Photo by The Economist on September 08, 2021. May be an image of 1 person.
Photo by The Economist on September 08, 2021. May be an image of 2 people.
Photo by The Economist on September 08, 2021. May be an image of 1 person.

Photo by The Economist on September 08, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Covid-19 patients with severe symptoms suffer long-lasting cognitive impairments Difference in global cognitive score relative to people who had not had covid-19, standard deviation units -0.8 -0.7 Symptoms but without respiratory symptoms -0.6 -0.5 -0.4 -0.3 -0.2 -0.1 Respiratory symptoms, no assistance at home Respiratory symptoms, medical assistance at home Went to hospital but was not put on a ventilator Standard error Went to hospital and was put on ventilator Source: "Cognitive deficits in people who have recovered from COVID-19", by A. Hampshire et al., EClinicalMedicine, 2021 The Economist'.

node.text:
To learn more about “brain fog” in sufferers of long covid, a group of scientists decided to dig into the effect of the coronavirus on mental ability.⁠
⁠
Some 80,000 participants completed various brain-function tests. ⁠
⁠
As this chart shows, even people who had milder covid-19 symptoms performed worse than those who thought they had never caught it. ⁠
⁠
The more severe the symptoms, the worse they performed. Those who had been put on a ventilator scored lower than people who reported having a learning disability or had previously had a stroke.⁠
⁠
In itself, that is not enough to conclude that covid-19 caused these differences in cognition. But there is growing evidence that the virus can affect the brain. ⁠
⁠
To find out how, click on the link in our bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 08, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The future of American power " The greatest menace for America's civilisation, like Rome's centuries ago, is the enemy within JorgeCastañ Castañeda'.

node.text:
"Rome had its highways and legal system, its aqueducts and taxes; America has everything from Hollywood to space travel, CNN and iPhones" writes Jorge Castañeda, the former foreign minister of Mexico, in a piece for The Economist.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Despite its internal problems, he argues, America will continue to prevail. As no other country can command as much power and influence as America. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
"The United States continues to be the only state capable of truly projecting military power throughout the globe, and not just in its surroundings" he writes.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Tap the link in our bio to read Jorge Castañeda's full essay on the future of American power.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @dan.will

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 08, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The future of American power " The greatest menace for America's civilisation, like Rome's centuries ago, is the enemy within JorgeCastañ Castañeda'.
Photo by The Economist on September 08, 2021. May be an illustration of 1 person and beard.

Photo by The Economist in London, United Kingdom. May be an image of 1 person, standing and text that says 'Britain Boris Johnson will break a promise and raise taxes to "fix" social care er CIAL CARE'.

node.text:
Boris Johnson vowed to fix the social-care crisis and to not raise taxes. Yet there is a problem with making contradictory promises: you can only keep one.⁠
⁠
Britain’s prime minister argued the covid-19 pandemic had unexpectedly increased costs for social care, which is true. Handily, the money can also be used to fund the prime minister’s social-care “fix”.⁠
⁠
The tax rise is popular, according to a recent poll. A plurality say it was acceptable to break the manifesto in order to fund social care. ⁠
⁠
But that may not tell the full story. Tap the link in our bio to find out why.⁠
⁠
Credit: Paul Edwards / WPA Pool / Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in Yemen. May be an image of 1 person, standing and sky.

node.text:
Both Barack Obama and Donald Trump tried and failed to turn their backs on the Middle East. Joe Biden is unlikely to do so either. However, America’s place in the region—measured in troop levels, diplomatic engagement or influence—is not what it was.⁠
⁠
The Arab world is too big and diverse to be dominated by one ideology. It needs greater unity, but of the boring, technocratic sort.⁠
⁠
Young populations need jobs, the energy transition may gut the budgets of oil-producing states and climate change could make parts of the region unfit to live in. ⁠
⁠
If the Arab world’s leaders cannot stop fighting over old ideologies, they may find there is nothing left to fight for. Read the full Special report on the Arab world by tapping the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Credit: Mohammed Hamoud/Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 07, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, standing and text that says 'Asia Yale-NUS the first liberal-arts college in Singapore, closes its doors YALF YALF-NUS COLLEG COLLEGE AVENUE'.

node.text:
When the current crop of first-years graduate, Yale-NUS, Singapore’s first liberal-arts college, will cease to exist.⁠
⁠
The university's launch was billed as a grand experiment testing whether an American-style liberal-arts education could sink roots in Asia.⁠
⁠
But at a meeting on August 27th administrators announced that the college’s programmes will be combined with another at NUS to form a new institution by 2022.⁠
⁠
The news came as a shock to students, teachers and the college president, Tan Tai Yong, who were not consulted.⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to find out if the decision could have been more to do with politics, rather than education.⁠
⁠
Credit: Roslan Rahman/AFP via Getty Images

What can America’s “gilded age” reveal about China’s future? On our “Money Talks” podcast we look back at a period in American history marked by tremendous growth married with inequality and corruption, and ask whether this might help us understand China’s near future.⁠
⁠
Also on the podcast, how the Delta variant is changing the direction of the world economy, and why video-gaming is China’s latest target in its crackdown on big technology.⁠
⁠
To hear more about markets, the economy and business, click the link in our bio to listen to “Money Talks”
